INVEST in Europe”– INFA Vocational Education, Skills and Training” – is a national mobility project promoted by INFA, Institut National de Formation et d’Application, involving its 8 regional delegations. Mainly focused on vocational training courses concerning the tourism, hospitality-catering and animation sectors, the project will enable 40 VET learners and 30 recent graduates by INFA to participate in a professional placement in one of the five European countries concerned. INFA considers international mobility as an asset for professionalization and access to the labour market for the youth and participants in VET. Thus, INVEST in Europe advocates for those mobility periods abroad as an integral part of the vocational training as well as the lifelong learning process, which will lead to the acquisition of new professional  and soft skills in another European country, it will enhance the professional competences already acquired and promote the global employability of the participants. Based on our expertise regarding the professionally-focused mobility projects, INVEST in Europe is implemented by INFA Europe, department in charge of the European projects for more than 10 years. It will notably contribute to an added value to the provided training in our Institutes.The project will also offer a mobility support to our trainers, training managers. Those mobilities will permit to monitor the trainees on site and especially to assist people having difficulties in order to avoid breaking course. The INVEST in Europe project is part of our strategic approach in terms of internationalization, part of modernization in vocational training, in which learners and staff mobility will have a multiplier effect and ensure that the project’s outcomes are disseminated and widely used within the organization.
Mobility Opportunities for Vocational Educational and International Training

The goal of ADICE, and of the project, is to ensure the social and professional development of the learners (including those with fewer opportunities), by participating in a valuable mobility experience. ADICE considers the mobility experience as a tool allowing the development of technical, transverse and social skills which favors employment. The project “MOVE IT: Mobility Opportunities for Vocational Educational and International Training” plans for two years, from the 1st of June 2016, the sending of 40 learners in vocational training, in mobility for purposes of learning, in the eligible countries of the European Union, planned in our partnership agreement: in United Kingdom, in Malta, in Italy, Ireland, Portugal, Germany, Spain, Poland, Romania and Greece. These mobility projects will be characterized by professional internships in companies or within non for profit organizations, and would last for 3, 6 or 10 months.These placements will be organized and defined according to the experience, sector of activity, professional project, needs, expectations at short and long term and the profile of the participants. Indeed, ADICE’s goal is to promote the European mobility, but also to fight against discriminations and to promote people with fewer opportunities at a social and professional level. Our public is diverse and so, our projects are, first of all, accessible to all local learners, without any discrimination, yet no level of studies is required or limited age, and also, characterized by destinations, durations, and various sectors of activity. They are fitted to the needs, objectives and profile of each person.  Applications are thus estimated with regard to all these criteria and on the motivation and relevance of the participant’s personal and professional project. At the level of the European partners, we work on one hand with intermediate structures who organize the mobility of the participants, and, thus, provide a support to the participants with more difficulties, and on the other hand, we work also more and more directly with host structures and companies. These structures are found, during the whole contract period, and especially selected for the mobility of a participant in specific areas. They also may have already hosted participant within their structure in past projects.Our partnership network is related to our internalization strategy. It is characterized by a geographical, linguistic and economic diversity (Germany, Ireland, Italy, Spain, Poland, the United Kingdom, etc.) a plurality of activities sectors adapted to every public (social, tourism, sale, communication, etc.) and of types of structures (companies, associations, training centers…) Every partner, whether it is a direct structure or intermediate structure, is in charge of providing a quality placement (within its structure or one of its local partners), if possible the accommodation, and a support if the participant is facing difficulties (in the activities, with the team, social or cultural difficulties, or a problem linked to the security of the participant). Indeed, the partner has to provide a quality follow-up during the mobility, and a relevant and fitted evaluation at the end.  The diversity of the partners allows us to answer the majority of the candidates’ needs. Thus, our international strategy aims to offer internships in companies as well as in associations, in a varied number of professional sectors and in a diversity of countries.Regarding the development at the European level, ADICE being a territorial actor of social and professional inclusion, our action plan is in complete relevance with the analysis of the needs at the territorial and sectorial level, but also for the public. Indeed, the Nord-Pas-De-Calais area is very affected by unemployment, which rate is largely exceeding the national rate (12.8%, while 10.0% in metropolitan France, especially for Young people aged from 15 to 24 years old, with a 23.6% unemployment rate, data given by INSEE for the 2nd trimester 2015). Moreover, the city of Roubaix knows a high economic development, but the rate of unemployment stays high and affects 22% of the local population. With mobility experience being an entrance to employment, it enables the development of new experiences, skills and opportunities to enrich the professional life, the project of ADICE is thus absolutely relevant at a local level, according to the territory priorities and background. Moreover, a project like this one, allows the development of the territory at a European level, the enlargement of the opportunities and network and the exchange and developpement of new skills among this local network, which is a real added value for our structure but also for the territory.

Pôle emploi wants to carry an Erasmus+ project for the 2017-2019 period in order to offer to jobseekers a European mobility opportunity. The purpose of the project is to allow them to gain work experience and complementary job skills (lilnguistic, personal, professional) in order to facilitate their inclusion in the labour market, both in France and Europe.
Thanks to the suggestions made during the audit on the 2014-2016 program of Erasmus + french agency, Pôle emploi wants to confirm its involvement in European and international mobility schemes as return to work tools consolidating the quality of the effects.
According to the European Commission and the French government expectations, the programme carried by Pôle emploi, for the fourth consecutive year, will complete the schemes already implemented.
A European mobility experience represents a key asset to get back a permanent job or to have access to a better training. A large proportion of the jobseekers, especially the less qualified and the most alienated from employment, are not aware of the different mobility opportunities although they represent the population directly concerned by the added value such experience represents.
According to its experience, its knowledge about the European labour market and the employers’ needs, especially in linguistic skills, Pôle emploi choose to target specific countries considering their needs in terms of labour workforces and employment opportunities as well as the language of work and/or the language of the country. Based on a reinforced partnership with mobility experts, European PES etc.
Pôle emploi wishes to continue the implementation of a longer mobility (6 months) for a part of the project. The implementation by Pôle emploi’s regions confirms that in some cases of accompanied mobility, a longer time is better for the jobseeker to acquire complementary skills and competences.
Participants will be jobseekers registered at Pôle emploi and for which a European mobility experience appear clearly as an added value in the paths to professional integration.
The validation of the mobility experience need is done through a professional diagnostic by the dedicated advisor and validated by the Erasmus+ contact person in each Pôle emploi’s regions. The jobseekers identified will present shortcoming in language skills and a need of complementary professional qualification.
As soon as they are selected, the participants will have access to the linguistic platform in order to make the evaluation and start their linguistic preparation.
Each participant will be in permanent contact with its dedicated advisor for the project.
Through workshops, Pôle emploi will prepare the participants before departure (2-3 weeks before the actual departure) in order to secure the mobility experiences. 
Through its experience in different mobility programs and finiancial assistance (Your First Eures Job 1 & 2, Reactivate), Pôle emploi wants to supplement the opportunities offered to job seekers by implementing Erasmus + again.
Improving ASE, Apprentice Personal Development and Recent Graduate Employment

This project focuses on improving the youth development of male footballers in England and Wales. The background and context to this is wide and complex but includes the following key factors: 

1. Male National Teams in international tournaments have underachieved given levels of investment in the game
2. European trained players are increasingly entering English/Welsh Senior teams instead of homegrown and very few English or Welsh players go into mainland Europe to play
3. Of the top 100 training clubs (those producing players performing in the top European Leagues) only 3 are English and 0 are Welsh (CIES data) - Holland, Spain and France have the most representatives 
4. At 18 years of age only 40% the 675 apprentices attached to professional Football League Clubs will be offered a contract
5. By 21 only 5% of a year group will still be playing professionally
6. Contrary to popular belief the vast majority of professional footballers cannot "retire for life"
7. Serious issues of loss of identity are experienced when investing everything into "success" of the pitch 
8. New thinking, now backed up by research, suggests that "Better People Make Better Players" 
 
This background and context raises a number of Performance, Identity, Well-Being and Transition/Dual Career challenges for young footballers and the coaching staff trying to develop them, so the following Strategic Objectives were created to address them:

1. Expose players/coaches to the philosophies and training environments which are producing players in Europe who are migrating to England/Wales 
2. Enable players/coaches to observe, experience, evaluate, improve and acquire new technical, tactical & physical skills/training techniques  
3. Facilitate Personal/Professional Development of players/coaches and the acquisition of greater self-knowledge, new behaviours and attitudes, cultural awareness, employability and language skills
4. Expand player/coach knowledge of labour market opportunities inside and outside of performance within Europe and encourage outward migration
5. Challenge players/coaches to take responsibility for embedding acquired knowledge and learning in to their everyday environments and programmes
6. Effect structural changes at the governing body level (Premier League/Football League/FA) and within the Apprenticeship framework based on European best practice
      
In order to create learning and development opportunities for the above objectives the following activities are proposed:

1. Two week training programme for 14 professional youth teams in Holland/Spain. 
Apprentice players are aged 16-18 and undertaking the Apprenticeship in Sporting Excellence (ASE) programme. 
This would give 280 apprentices an opportunity to learn and develop.  
2. Twelve week placement programme for 30 recent graduates of ASE NOT offered professional terms at their club upon completion of the programme to Sweden/Spain
3. One week job shadow for 15 Professional Development Phase coaches at The Spanish FA/in Spanish Clubs 

We use a planning matrix which maps Strategic Objectives to particular Mobility Activities, desired Learning Outcomes and finally into the ASE qualification standards/Key Questions to gather evidence of learning.  

Ultimately we expect the mobilities to create self-reflection and develop self-knowledge, inspire participants to effect change in themselves, at their level and at whatever level they are able to influence beyond themselves and their immediate environment. 
A player is able to effect personal change and those of his team mates and even inspire change in his coaches if he has the interpersonal skills and confidence to challenge them in the right way. The coaches are able to effect personal change and changes in their club programmes to have a positive impact on their current and future players, the wider ASE programme and indeed into the foundations of English and Welsh player development standards and the FA coaching curriculum moving forward. LFE can also take this to the UEFA level with support from the PL/EFL and FA and want to facilitate and support all such changes.

We also expect that the training and surrounding social environments in Europe allow/target the creation of better people (i.e. whole person development) rather than simply focusing on technical, tactical and physical development and which is the missing element of the English and Welsh training programmes.

The regional mobility platform in Hauts-de-France, "Ready to Move" aims to ensure access to mobility for all young people regardless of their situation and especially for those being the most remote from mobility. The "Ready for a Job" project is an integral part of this platform, as such, for a year; the actors involved in this platform are considering the implementation of a common project. "Ready for a job" is part of this effort, bringing together 5 members of the platform, working in favor of youth mobility within a consortium: Local Missions of Douaisis and Lille, Francas, CEMEA and Léo Lagrange Nord-Ile de France.

"Ready for a job" is a way of pooling members of the network in terms of coordinating, preparing and supporting young people (school leavers, NEETs) from the territory to mobility as a key to professional and personal success.

The goals are:
- Gain of professional skills,
- Empowerment of an audience with less opportunity and professional difficulties,
- Discovery of a specific profession in an intercultural environment.

The aim is to promote training and employment opportunities in order to facilitate the integration of young people into adult life by means of adapted and comprehensive support that prepare them both for mobility and re-employment . The 244 youngsters that will benefit of the grants are mainly aged between 18 and 30 and among them there are school leavers, others followed by training centers, local missions and the job center. Particular attention will be given to young people lacking opportunities, school dropouts and people with fewer opportunities. 

The activities set up during the deployment of this project will concern the promotion of the Erasmus + program, through the platform’s outreach antennas, informing and supporting participants towards mobility, valuing learning outcomes and dissemination of the results of this project. 

Through exchanges on our practices, by pooling our tools and resources, at the level of the platform, we will allow future participants to benefit from a preparation that is intercultural and linguistic, practical and professional. Each member, as the sending organization, will be in charge of the follow-up of its participants, in liaison with the host organization. For each audience, we thought of an internship period in line with its needs and limits to meet their expectations. Each member of the consortium has specific expertise that will be used in the implementation of the planned activities. By creating a COPIL consisting of at least the key people of each member of the consortium, we will ensure the implementation of the project's quality charter by enforcing the obligations of each structure. To ensure financial and administrative follow-up, the coordinating organization will put in place ad hoc tools for the constant monitoring of the grants allocated. The consortium believes that COPIL is an essential element in the management and monitoring of the project, while facilitating relations between members. 

The consortium wishes, through Erasmus +, to democratize access to mobility above all, paying attention to the integration of young "neet", such as those who drop out of school, with little or no qualifications. In order to encourage their adherence to the project and in view of the difficulties they may encounter individually, the consortium wishes to introduce an approach in the field of active pedagogy resulting from informal education. In the short term, we aim at developing autonomy and adaptability of the youngsters, openness to other cultures, increasing in professional skills and develop a sense of responsibility. Over the long term, the project may lead to young people returning to work, particularly within the 6 months following their return from mobility. Companies are increasingly open to independent, versatile and "mobile" profiles. Finally, we hope to stimulate a regional dynamic that will allow "new carriers" to take this type of European project. 

"Ready to Move" platform and by the same token the consortium brings together actors from all walks of life and working in different fields. This synergy makes it possible to apprehend all the potential difficulties that may possibly hinder the actions undertaken. We hope to launch a dynamic that will be able to respond to the initiatives implemented during these two years and to rebound on a project of even greater scale and greater geographical scope in 2019.

"Erasmus+ : a springboard to the future" is a project managed by "La Maison de l'Europe de Niort et des Deux-Sèvres", which aims at enabling young people between 18 and 30 years old who have just left vocational training for less than one year, who are monitored by the Mission Locale (French agency helping young people between 16 and 25 years old with their professional integration) and/or Pôle Emploi (French employment agency) and who are living in the Deux-Sèvres department to benefit from professional training abroad during 3 or 6 months. Our main target audience is young people who may think they are excluded from mobility programs, who are not highly qualified (no more than a 3-year degree) and who are having problems with social and vocational insertion. This project includes a job shadowing mobility in the organisation of our new partner in Germany, this mobility will be experienced by one volunteer from the board in order to integrate the volunteers of MDE in european projects.
This initiative takes place in a very rural department (the Deux-Sèvres) in which youth unemployment rate is quite high and where there are no universities.
Our main aim is that the participants in the project will develop personal, professional and linguistic skills which will help them with their entry into working life. They will benefit from a rewarding intercultural experience - this is clearly an asset to achieve their career plans.
"La Maison de l’Europe de Niort et des Deux-Sèvres" (MDENDS) works together with the Missions Locales (ML) in the department and their counselors specialized in European programs. The counselors act as link people between the MDE and the other employees of the MLs. They also participate in monitoring committees once every six months.
On our own, we work on the personal and professional goals of every participant. Nevertheless, our jobs are closely linked so that everyone can access the programs, even the ones who think they are excluded from mobility.
Three waves of departure are planned in September, January and April so that we can set up preparatory meetings before everyone leaves.
For this project, we are planning to send 15 young professional abroad (8 six-month placements and 7 three-month placements) in Ireland, Italy, Spain, Germany or the United Kingdom. We will decide of the time abroad according to each participant’s profile. The same goes for the place, the choice will be made according to what the participant thinks it is the best. In eachcountry, our intermediate partners will be looking for internship setting locations, as required by the participants.
With this project, we wish to maintain the close cooperation we have built for years with the "Missions Locales" and our European partners. We also hope that this experience will be a perfect springboard for each participant professionally and personally. At a local level, we want to act for youth employment, which has been declared a national priority.
Zwiększ swoje szanse na zatrudnienie w swoim zawodzie po zakończeniu edukacji

There are 45 students (3 groups of 15 students) and 6 graduates willing to undergo a vocational training in Spain (Granada, Seville) and Great Britain (Preston). Students are of the third grade at Zespół Szkół Technicznych i Ogólnokształcących /the Technical and General Education School Complex/ in Bytom, Poland specializing in IT, mechatronics and economics. The training is going to be held in 2017, 2018 and 2019 in Spanish companies dealing directly with IT branches, in particular with computer graphics, web design, network administration, maintenance and programming, and in Irish ones - mechatronics branch (car mechatronics, production lines, control systems) and economics (running a company, accounting). There are many foreign companies involved in a project. Most of them have already cooperated or still cooperate with ZSTiO within the framework of Erasmus+, Leonardo da Vinci and ESF programmes.

The project aims at students' (graduates) professional development, the understanding of operation of foreign and international companies, comparing working methods between Poland and the target country, learning how to cooperate efficiently in an international team and presenting novel and new technological solutions. The secondary goal is to promote language learning, professional language use and the culture and organization of work different from the native one.

The main purpose behind the project is to satisfy the requirements named above. Besides, the project aim is to meet the policy of modern European education: mobility in terms of vocational education, cooperation between educational entities, development of vocational training programs, better transparency in and transfer of vocational qualifications, IT application in lifelong education, and last but not least, in terms of the all-European meaning of education as such.

The project results derive directly from the needs and aims rooted in the project; the most salient involving: better chances to find a job after graduation or set up the own one (according to job centre in Bytom, unemployment rate in year 2016 is at 16% level), strengthening self-confidence and ability to cope with stressful situations, breaking language and culture-based barriers, strengthening the awareness of cross-European dimension of individual education, learning creative thinking and reasoning skills and to promote our school in the local and regional community.

The participating students/graduates undergo the recruitment procedure and meet its criteria. Most of participants are of full legal age. The project involves teachers from our school who are responsible for preparing the students willing to meet the project's language, vocational and cultural objectives. The integral part of the preparation includes evaluation and promotion after the mobility. There is a school coordinator appointed as a person responsible for management of the project and its proper course during the individual stages (information, recruitment, preparation, tickets and insurance, contacts with parents, training, evaluation, report). During the trainig session participants (exluding graduates) are accompanied by a teacher who directly supervises all participants, helps them and takes any decision on behalf of school headmaster.

No students/graduates with special needs will be engaged in the project.
L'Europe de demain, l'Europe dans nos mains !

The "Europe of Tomorrow, Europe in Our Hands" project is a 3-day "training" seminar for 50 youth workers, bringing together members of the Léo Lagrange network (employees, volunteers, administrators, volunteers) all over France and European partners active in the fields of youth and European projects. Young former beneficiaries of Erasmus + projects, European volunteers and civic service volunteers as well as OFAJ ambassadors will be invited to the seminar. The purpose of this thematic reunion is to enable European mobility players to meet and discuss about the future of Europe by 2020 following the latest political and social developments that are weakening the foundations of our European community. This seminar is in line with the goals of the Erasmus + program and more precisely those of the action KA1 "Mobility of the youth actors", in fact:

1) target participants are or have been active actors in the field of youth
2) the aim of this type of Erasmus + project echoes the purpose of the seminar, namely the professional development of the actors,
3)share the objectives of Erasmus +: encouraging interaction between actors, strengthening European cooperation, discovering youth work.

The need identified is to promote the hosting within the structures that have never yet seized this opportunity; the seminar also wants to meet the needs of the partners leader in the hosting projects. Indeed, the activities planned will allow them to reflect on the causes of certain difficulties encountered in hosting projects and to revitalize practices already acquired by setting up a hosting protocol for beneficiaries with specific needs or less opportunity. The objectives of this meeting will therefore be:

- to strengthen European cooperation
- to discover/ improve youth work in an intercultural context
- to exchange around professional practices
- to develop common working methods for future partnerships / projects
- to increase and support projects aimed at hosting young people and / or professionals

The activities planned for the development of the identified objectives will be group workshops aiming to analyze the hosting process in all the key stages in order to facilitate the access to the projects and thus to promote more this program.

This project will positively influence the direct and indirect beneficiaries as it responds concretely to the needs identified during its conception. The meeting will provide specific responses through the development of ad hoc activities to achieve the objectives. In the short term, the participants will be able both to acquire skills in hosting projects and to renew the dynamics already acquired. In the long term, we believe that with this exchange, the European partners present will be able to design a new approach to mobility and hospitality projects, taking into account the social and political context of present and future Europe. Regarding the management of the project, we wish to keep a very collaborative and transparent management of any decision and follow-up of the quality of the seminar. We will put in place an "open method of coordination, to share data, online meetings, information / advice at a distance." During the three days convention, the partners will have their own place for the animation and moderation of the debates. Methodology will also be deployed in the final evaluation phase of the project, dissemination of results and promotion of the pocket-book of good hosting. Mobility will be assessed using formal and non-formal tools and participants will reflect on their learning during the first phase and on their personal expectations. During this stage, SWOT analysis will be again the point of departure in order to identify if the difficulties, opportunities or weaknesses of each organization have been well treated and solved. At the end of the Europe 202 program 0, it would be worth considering bringing together all the participants reunited again to follow-up to the seminar and to adapt the hosting protocol pocket-book to the new needs and challenges identified in the context post Europe 2020.

Signed Voices is a youth exchange project which aims to promote cultural and social inclusion for Deaf young people, and intercultural awareness and understanding between Deaf and hearing people, and between different European countries. This is a non-formal education project using heritage investigation through film as the medium to motivate and develop the skills and self-confidence of young Deaf people.

The majority of hearing societies across the EU (indeed across the world) fail to truly recognise Deaf people who use sign language as a first or preferred language positively as a cultural and linguistic minority group.  Deaf people face barriers in accessing many services and activities which hearing people access freely without barriers.

Deaf people, their sign languages and their culture have a great deal to offer - not only to Deaf people, but also to hearing people and society. There is strength, pride, encouragement and enhanced positive self esteem to be had from meeting, working with and developing friendships with Deaf young people from other parts of the EU.  Learning about the lives of other EU citizens who are Deaf contributes to a greater sense of being European.

This application is based on our ongoing "Signed Voices" heritage project in the NW of England, which is all about capturing the Deaf Community’s memories, experiences and contemporary values; showcasing them now, and preserving them for future generations. Exploring our own and others' heritage is a gateway to pride, respect and identity. Yet, most people do not know what “Deaf Heritage” means and are unaware that British Sign Language (BSL) is a complex language with its own grammar and art forms. Deaf people who use BSL have their own cultural and linguistic heritage. However, they have fewer opportunities than other native language groups in the UK to consider heritage.

Signed Voices is an ‘oral history project’ with BSL at its core. It enables members of the Deaf Community to share their heritage with a wider community and creates a lasting legacy. Deafway works with Deaf volunteers to film memories and contemporary thoughts, in short semi-structured interviews – conducted in BSL by pairs of young people who decide their own interview topic. This culminates in a live celebration and reflection event and a final exhibition which will be available to tour.

This Erasmus+ project will extend the methodology, results and impact of Signed Voices to four other European countries (Estonia, Poland, Greece and Netherlands) while also helping us to extend the project within the UK. The project will address the fact that there continues to be a dearth of opportunity for Deaf and hearing people to engage with Deaf heritage and to embrace feelings of pride and identity in relation to each country's Deaf heritage. We believe this will bring a new (or at least rarely seen) dimension to the Erasmus+ programme, with excellent prospects for visibility and dissemination.

20 Deaf young people from 5 countries (Estonia, Greece, Italy, Poland and UK) will take part in this project. in Preston, UK in summer 2018. All will be sign language users and different sign languages (principally BSL and international sign) will be the principal medium of communication on the project. The methods used will be exclusively non-formal education (interactive, team based) with a strong intercultural learning element.

The impact we are looking for is a model of good practice in intercultural communication between and beyond different Sign Language user communities, developed through Erasmus+. We hope the approaches developed by this project will be recognised and promoted by and through National Agencies. We are willing to share the methodology of this project with other organisations and networks around Europe. We would like this project to be the first in a series and to lead to a widening network.

The project is included in a logic of continuity, in the internationalization process already initiated by the members of the Consortium and consolidated over the years through the design and management of mobility projects abroad for students and teaching staff.
The Consortium intends to fulfil the commitments defined in the European Internationalization Strategy 2016-2020 not only continuing the activities already being implemented but encouraging participation in new international projects, reinforcing European networks and promoting the learning of foreign languages.
In this perspective, the project will provide 125 students the opportunity to undertake work-based learning pathways abroad in France, Spain, Germany, Finland, United Kingdom and Ireland with the aim to promote:
- the development of vocational skills in international working environments to gain a comprehensive view of the business dynamics in sectors  consistent with the field of study
- the strengthening of linguistic and relational competencies by relating to cultures different from their own and expanding the sense of European citizenship
- the improvement of some key curricular skills required by the labor market, in particular, the development of autonomy and creativity, the ability to analyze problems, etc.
- the valorization of their own potentialities to increase confidence in themselves and in their abilities.
The project also envisages the involvement of 6 teachers in order to promote: the improvement of the learning process; the development of a training offer coherent with local needs and projected towards international horizons; knowledge and understanding of educational policies and practices of the host countries with a view of comparison and mutual integration as well as the improvement of methodological and language skills also enabling the implementation of CLIL methodology in the teaching of vocational subjects of the different curricula.
The Consortium will provide students with ongoing support during their stay abroad. The high percentage of underage beneficiaries requires the involvement of carefully selected group leaders who will play a key role in facilitating the socio-cultural integration in the host country and the supervision and monitoring of mobility activities.
As outlined in the European development Strategy, the Consortium members are committed to strengthen the internationalization process continuing in the promotion and implementation of international activities already undertaken.
Currently Two projects Erasmus + KA1-2016-1-KA102-005082 IT01 and IT01-016-1-KA102-005083 are currently being implemented, coordinated by CPV, which foresee 30-days mobility flows in 10 EU countries and are targeted, respectively, at 175 and 104 students of technical and professional institutes. The Consortium Institutes participate by sending students from different fields of study.
In order to connect the overall strategy of the school with the design of students’ mobility schemes, training, tutoring activities, updating and job shadowing abroad through the participation of teaching staff will be promoted in the framework of Erasmus + KA1 and Learning event in eTwinning projects.
CPV is likewise engaged in the:
• support for the management of no. Erasmus + mobility Traineeship on behalf of 'ITS "COSMO", ECHE holder
• strengthening and improvement of incoming mobility services 
• Fine-tuning and full implementation of on-line tools for managing all phases of mobility projects.
CPV has also activated a service for the implementation of transnational extra-curricular work placements and job mobility placements in the framework of Youth Guarantee Program providing support in the selection of candidates, identification of host foreign companies, logistics organization and monitoring.
As part of language teaching, the commitment of the Institutes of the Consortium continues in expanding the offer of language courses for the preparation and obtaining of language certificates in diffrent languages (Cambridge ESOL, Dele, Delf, ZD).
In this context, the Institutes “A. Ceccato”, “A. Fusinieri” and “A Rossi”, in cooperation with CPV, have recently submitted project proposals in the framework of the ESF-funded initiative “MOVE 4.0, which foresees language training actions in the Veneto Region and abroad.
As for teacher training for CLIL methodology, the Institutes intend to continue promoting pilot actions by encouraging participation in methodological courses and the collection and sharing of teaching materials useful for the preparation of lessons.
The Institutes aim to broaden the offer of cultural exchanges and study trips abroad involving a greater number of students, providing teachers the necessary organizational tools and consolidating existing European networks.

ADICE specializes in youth mobility and coordinating French and European mobility projects for more than 15 years. Our expertise  through all these projects has been strengthened over the years and we have developped high quality tools (mobility passport, skills booklet...) to support better all participants in their project.

The goal of ADICE, and of the project, is to ensure the social and professional development of the learners (including those with fewer opportunities), by participating in a valuable mobility experience. ADICE considers the mobility experience as a tool allowing the development of technical, transverse and social skills which favors employment. 

The project “LUCIE: Learning Unique Competencies In Europe” plans for two years, from the 1st of June 2017, the sending of 30 learners in vocational training, in mobility for purposes of learning, in the eligible countries of the European Union, planned in our partnership agreement: in United Kingdom, Italy, Ireland, Portugal, Germany, Spain and Czech Republic. These mobility projects will be characterized by professional internships in companies or within non for profit organizations, and would last for 3, 6 or 10 months.

These placements will be organized and defined according to the experience, sector of activity, professional project, needs, expectations at short and long term and the profile of the participants. Indeed, ADICE’s goal is to promote the European mobility, but also to fight against discriminations and to promote people with fewer opportunities at a social and professional level. Our public is diverse and so, our projects are, first of all, accessible to all local learners, without any discrimination, yet no level of studies is required or limited age, and also, characterized by destinations, durations, and various sectors of activity. They are fitted to the needs, objectives and profile of each person. Participants are supported with regard to all these criteria and on the motivation and relevance of the participant’s personal and professional project. 

At the level of the European partners, we work on one hand with intermediate structures which organize the mobility of the participants, and, thus, provide a support to the participants with more difficulties, and on the other hand, we work also more and more directly with host structures and companies. These structures are found, during the whole contract period, and especially selected for the mobility of a participant in specific areas. They also may have already hosted participant within their structure in past projects.
Our partnership network is related to our internalization strategy. It is characterized by a geographical, linguistic and economic diversity a plurality of activities sectors adapted to every public (social, tourism, sale, communication, etc.) and of types of structures (companies, associations, training centers…) Every partner, whether it is a direct structure or intermediate structure, is in charge of providing a quality placement (within its structure or one of its local partners), if possible the accommodation, and a support if the participant is facing difficulties (in the activities, with the team, social or cultural difficulties, or a problem linked to the security of the participant). Indeed, the partner has to provide a quality follow-up during the mobility, and a relevant and fitted evaluation at the end. The diversity of the partners allows us to offer a large panel of relevant opportunities to the participants’ needs and careers. Thus, our international strategy aims at offering internships in companies as well as in associations, in a varied number of professional sectors and in a diversity of countries.

Regarding the development at the European level, ADICE being a territorial actor of social and professional inclusion, our action plan is in complete relevance with the analysis of the needs at the territorial and sectorial level, but also for the public. Indeed, the Hauts-de-France area is very affected by unemployment, which rate is higher than other area and largely exceeding the national rate (12%, while 9.6% in metropolitan France data given by INSEE for the 2nd trimester 2016). Moreover, the city of Roubaix knows a high economic development, but the rate of unemployment stays high and affects 30.9% of the local population. 
With mobility experience being an entrance to employment, it enables the development of new experiences, skills and opportunities to enrich the professional life, the project of ADICE is thus absolutely relevant at a local level, according to the territory priorities and background. Moreover, a project like this one, allows the development of the territory at a European level, the enlargement of the opportunities and network and the exchange and developpement of new skills among this local network, which is a real added value for our structure but also for the territory.
Mit Auslandserfahrung punkten - man lernt mehr als man denkt

The project ‚Get ahead with un internship abroad—you learn more than you think’ builds on the previous projects carried out by the Nürnberger Fremdprachenschule, a college which trains students to qualify as state certified multilingual office assistants. The objective of all our projects is to enable our students to gain practical experience working in companies in Europe, as the training offered by our college is purely academic and has no practical component.
The specific aim of this project is to make it possible for our students to gain an insight into how international companies operate and thus improve their chances on the European/international job market. By improving their work-relevant language skills, especially their oral proficiency, and their intercultural competence, participants in the scheme can devolop both at a personal and a professional level, sharpen their individual profile and embark on their working life with a high degree of competence and self-confidence. In addition, the objective of the project is to raise their awareness of European issues.
Twenty-two students and one teacher will take part in the project. The students are all young adults aged 18 and above. For most, the training course at our college is the first training they do after leaving school.
Completing an internship in an international company, be it in tourism, administration, trade and industry or imports/exports, enables the participants to put what they have learnt at our college into practice and helps them to see how versatile the profession which they have trained for is. They can work in trade and industry, gain experience in dealing with customers, learn to work in a team, translate documents and much more. The school works closely together with agencies in each country. Learning targets are set out and the students are supervised by mentors: they have to complete a learning diary and have regular meetings with the mentors.
This project aims to sharpen the students’ understanding that taking part in a European internship not only improves their language proficiency but also enhances other skills. The students are expected to document what they have learnt and become aware that in addition to business skills, the internship gives them an insight into other aspects of life abroad which they may not be aware of at first sight. They are encouraged to reflect on aspects such as cultural differences, traditions, eating culture, body 
At the end of the project, the participants will have a clearer view of their professional future and as a result find it easier to find employment. In addition, they should become more willing to travel and develop more tolerance and openness towards other cultures.
The participants are expected to pass on their experiences to other young people in our school, at education fairs and other information events and thus act as multiplicators, motivating them to take part in similar mobility projects. A further, long-term effect that is not to be underestimated is the improvement of teaching, as the experiences the participants have had are evaluated by the teachers and are integrated into their lessons. In this way, the quality of our training is always under scrutiny and is continually being optimised. The mobility of teachers who visit companies and the agencies we work with to observe the working practices there also contributes towards improving the teaching quality at our school. The teachers gain an insight into working methods and are then able to pass on these insights to their colleagues in the school, who can make additions to their lessons to cover language points and aspects of working life that had previously been lacking.
JUMP ! (Jobs Unemployed Mobility Project) ou Projet pour favoriser l'Emploi par la Mobilité

Unemployed people in the Southern French Region of Occitanie seldom think of looking for a better future elsewhere in Europe.  

The JUMP ! (Jobs Unemployed Mobility Project !) project's goals is to provide these people with new horizons. European horizons and more specificaly anglosaxon horizons (anglosaxon because that is their primary need, and that is also the request of the projects co-financer, the Region Occitanie). To get them thinking along lateral lines about what futures they could potentialy create for themselves elsewhere in Europe. And what futures they might have right here in the southern French region of Occitania by becoming a slightly different person, a professionnal who speaks decent English and has work experience in an anglophone context. 

The JUMP ! projects ambition is to send 20 job seekers for a job placement somewhere else in Europe, in an anglophone context, for 6 week periods.  The project will be co - financed by the Region Occitanie in the south of France. Candidates will be prepared linguistically and culturally for a period of 5 to 10 weeks in our language school. 

This project will achieve the following : 

1) Open up international horizons for the 20 learners as well as a much larger number of people that will be involved on the sides as potential candidates, recipiendaries of our corporate communication, co-funding organisations (Region Occitanie and Pôle Emploi (French Job Centre) especially) etc. 

2) Open new horizons for the VICTORIA'S English network of 25 language schools in France by providing a first involvement in ERASMUS + and providing first contacts towards the internationalisation of our network and the benchmarking of our methodologies and pedagogical approaches.

3) Create a local network of european cooperation linking our region of Occitanie to other regions in Europe and thus promoting the european ideals of free movement of labor and ideas.
Enhancing ASE, Progression, Personal Development and Recent Graduate Employment

This project focuses on improving the youth development of male footballers in England and Wales. 

The background and context to this is wide and complex but includes the following key factors: 
1. Male National Teams in international tournaments have underachieved given levels of investment in the game
2. European trained players are increasingly entering English/Welsh Senior teams instead of homegrown and very few English or Welsh players go into mainland Europe to play
3. Of the top 100 training clubs (those producing players performing in the top European Leagues) only 3 are English and 0 are Welsh (CIES data) - Holland, Spain and France have the most representatives 
4. At 18 years of age only 40% the 675 apprentices attached to professional English Football League Clubs will be offered a contract
5. By 21 only 5% of a year group will still be playing professionally
6. Contrary to popular belief the vast majority of professional footballers cannot "retire for life"
7. Serious issues of loss of identity are experienced when investing everything into "success" on the pitch 
8. New thinking, now backed up by research, suggests that "Better People Make Better Players" 
 
This background and context raises a number of Performance, Identity, Well-Being and Transition/Dual Career challenges for young footballers and the coaching staff trying to develop them, so the following Strategic Objectives were created to address them:

1. Expose players/coaches to the philosophies and training environments which are producing players in Europe who are migrating to England/Wales 
2. Enable players/coaches to observe, experience, evaluate, improve and acquire new technical, tactical & physical skills/training techniques  
3. Facilitate Personal/Professional Development of players/coaches and the acquisition of greater self-knowledge, new behaviours and attitudes, cultural awareness, employability and language skills
4. Expand player/coach knowledge of labour market opportunities inside and outside of performance within Europe and encourage outward migration
5. Challenge players/coaches to take responsibility for embedding acquired knowledge and learning in to their everyday environments and programmes
6. Effect structural changes at the governing body level (Premier League/Football League/FA) and within the Apprenticeship framework based on European best practice
      
In order to create learning and development opportunities for the above objectives the following activities are proposed:

1. Two week training programme for 14 professional youth teams in Holland/Spain. 
Apprentice players are aged 16-18 and undertaking the Apprenticeship in Sporting Excellence (ASE) programme. 
This would give 280 apprentices an opportunity to learn and develop. 

2. Twelve week placement programme for 30 recent graduates of ASE NOT offered professional terms at their club upon completion of the programme to Sweden/Spain

3. One week job shadow for 15 Professional Development Phase coaches at The Spanish FA/in Spanish Clubs 

We use a planning matrix which maps Strategic Objectives to particular Mobility Activities, desired Learning Outcomes and finally into the ASE qualification standards/Key Questions to gather evidence of learning.  

Ultimately we expect the mobilities to create self-reflection and develop self-knowledge, inspire participants to effect change in themselves, at their level and at whatever level they are able to influence beyond themselves and their immediate environment.
 
A player is able to effect personal change and those of his team mates and even inspire change in his coaches if he has the interpersonal skills and confidence to challenge them in the right way. The coaches are able to effect personal change and changes in their club programmes to have a positive impact on their current and future players, the wider ASE programme and indeed into the foundations of English and Welsh player development standards and the FA coaching curriculum moving forward. LFE can also take this to the UEFA level with support from the PL/EFL and FA and want to facilitate and support all such changes.

We also expect that the training and surrounding social environments in Europe allow/target the creation of better people (i.e. whole person development) rather than simply focusing on technical, tactical and physical development and which is the missing element of the English and Welsh training programmes.
Jeunes d'Est Ensemble en Mobilité Européenne

JEEME – 2018 « Jeunes d’Est Ensemble en Mobilité Européenne » (european mobility for Est Ensemble youth), is a new project carried as a mixed Consortium which federates 4 organisations established in the conurbation of «Est Ensemble» in the department «Seine-Saint-Denis», specialised in the field of professional integration support, and 5 European partners experienced in the reception and qualification of European trainees.

Coordinated by the IERF (European Research and Training Institute), holder of the Vocational Training Mobility Charter, the Consortium proposes to implement qualifying mobility pathways to enable 54 job-searching participants, 18-25 years old young people in integration and adults in career changes, to professionalise and strengthen their employability in the aim of a sustainable integration into the labor market.

The major prerogative of the JEEME project lies in the implementation of structured mobility schemes allowing participants of various levels, ages and professional backgrounds to develop job-related skills, technical-linguistic and intercultural skills, and this at the most appropriate moment of their professional evolution.

One of the principal advantages of the teaching programme resides in the cross-fertilisation between these 3 aspects which make up the whole experience. To help the students attain this goal, we have devised two mobility “road-maps”: the first lasting 8 weeks, particularly geared to young people in integration with an educational level from V to II, the second of 12 weeks targeted at participants of a higher level, either older or with longer professional experience. Whilst the periods of mobility can vary, the teaching plan contains the same stages and objectives:

1. Pre-departure: collective socioprofessional guidance sessions accompanied by individual assessments. Intercultural and language preparation.

2. Abroad (outside France): practical internship in a company meeting the profile or personal project of each participant, with constant monitoring to measure linguistic and professional progress, certified by Europass and level tests.

3. On return to France: session to assess what has been learnt from this experience, followed by accompaniment during 3 to 6 months to allow the participants to:

- Develop their capacity to summarise and explain in their own words the key skills acquired in relation to the specific professional context they have chosen.

- Learn to identify what experience and training is most relevant to maintaining a competitive professional profile on the job market, this in a logic of “Long Life Learning”.

- Acquire a continuous ability to judge their own progress, their technical, linguistic and intercultural skills, enabling them to position themselves to advantage vis-à-vis European or international recruiters.

- Identify concrete employment opportunities: a major indicator of the impact of our project is the integration in the job market.

The choice of destinations was determined by listing the job offers of the companies in the territory and the needs of the participants we wish to host within the project. Thus, 44 mobilities, divided into 5 flows, will take place in English-speaking countries: United Kingdom, Ireland, Malta, Cyprus. JEEME is also aimed at young people between 18 and 25 years old who have migrant backgrounds, with few opportunities and little knowledge of French, for which we have declined a mobility flow in Brussels.
There are numerous results expected by the members of the Consortium:

- Inscribe the sustainability of the project at a territorial level and broaden the Consortium's partnership basis by promoting the internationalisation of other organisations working in the fields of employment support, education and training.

- Promoting mobility initiatives as a qualification and employability tool for people in integration and contribute to the development and certification of the knowledge acquired during the mobility period from employment professionals and companies.

- Raise awareness among prescribing public authorities to include dedicated budget lines in complementary calls to the Erasmus + programme in order to multiply internship opportunities for internships for people in integration.
Mobilność uczniów i nauczycieli "Ekonoma" gwarancją sukcesu zawodowego

The promoter of the project is Zespół Szkół Ekonomiczno-Usługowych [ZSE-U] in Bytów. The project shall be carried out throughout month of May in years 2019 and 2020. The intermediating partners are as follows: Centre of Vocational Training in Schmalkalden, Germany; UK Work Placement in Preston, England and ESMOWIA in Valencia, Spain. The receiving parties will be the leading enterprises which will host 56 students who will carry their four-week internship in May 2019 and 2020. The participants are third grade students. They are going to conduct the work placements in specialised enterprises in Thuringia, Germany; the most modern establishments in Preston, England and exclusive hotels and tourist centres in Valencia, Spain. In addition to this, two groups of eight vocational teachers each will participate in a week-long job-shadowing experiences in May 2019 and May 2020; these are organised by our intermediating partner in Sirnitz, Austria - Bildungsberatung und Vermittlungsagentur. The aforementioned project meets the needs of modern vocational training and helps the students reach for success in their private and professional life alike. Students’ and teachers’ participation will be a grand step in personal development of the two groups. Furthermore, it will reinforce applicants with domestic and European job markets allowing them to raise their self-esteem and the sense of professionalism this will help the school, known on the local market as the Ekonom, bloom on educational and professional levels.  
The objectives of this project are: 
1. Equipping the participants with, both, practical experience and professional knowledge in accordance to the highest standards of the know-how in providing a broad variety services in countries of the western EU 
2. Improvement of school’s quality and its international dimension through global  cooperation, innovation, teamwork and staff integration 
3. Counteracting the unemployment among young people, especially women, as well as social exclusion among graduates from vocational schools 
4. Promotion of employees' mobility on a European job market 
5. Enhancement of students' and teachers’ competences, both personal and social ones through teaching resourcefulness and creativity, mobility and universal personal and cultural development 
6. Strict integration of the vocational training and the employment throughout gained knowledge and experience in the  real life conditions 
7. Adjusting professional qualifications of the trainees to the needs of job market 
8. Raising professional qualifications of the staff in order to implementing more effective educational methods, including dual education 
9. Training, improvement and promotion of students practical multi-language skills and experiences 
The school and its partners have appropriate staff resources as well as vast experience gained through directing numerous  exchange projects which guarantees completing abovementioned objectives and projected results, i.e.: 56 work placements, 16 job shadowing placements, the same number of EuroPass documents and certificates confirming the formal qualifications. The participants shall receive necessary security and protection, full logistic backup ensured by the school and the partners. Each student group will be accompanied by a partnering person – a teacher from the sending party. The recruitment process shall be completed in manner that is clear and comprehensible to both groups, the teachers and the participants. 
The project will be comprehensively monitored, evaluated and widespread. Unification of domestic and European qualifications will be achieved. Rational actions at the stage of planning, realization and evaluation of the project secure that all partners will contribute expectedly. Taking part in the project will increase participants' key competences and practical skills. As the local entrepreneurs took an active part in making suggestions as for the mobility’s program, we can be sure that it will increase proficiencies  sought by the local market. Next, locally, there will be implementation of good examples from countries with the best governance, efficiency , work etiquette and teaching and learning techniques. 
Finally, the participants will gain skills of using knowledge in new situations, integrating technology with training and self-development, what is an optimal way of creative actions in professional and social life of young people. Thanks to gained language skills, the internship will empower the position of beneficiaries on the real job market. The scope of cooperation between the school and foreign enterprises will increase, which will influence the development of the school. Vocational education will gain new quality and will become trendy among middle school students. The project will be an impulse to economic development. All of these will consolidate the position of the school as the school of success.
Zwiększenie szans na dobrą pracę poprzez staże zagraniczne

There are fifty five students participating in this project  (3 groups – 15 students each, 1 group – consisting of 10 persons) as well as two graduates who are going to do an internship in Spain (Seville, Granada) and Great Britain (Preston). They are the third grade students of Technical Secondary School Complex (ZSTiO) of the following professions: IT Technician, Mechatronics Technician, Economic Technician, Renewable Energy Systems and Devices Technician.
Internships will be held during the years 2018, 2019 and 2020, in Spanish companies dealing with IT industry, especially computer graphics, web design, computer network administration and programming; Renewable Energy Systems and Devices Industry (photovoltaic panels and solar collectors); in British companies –Mechatronics Industry  (automotive mechatronics, production lines, control systems) and Economics (company management, accountancy). There are many foreign companies participating in this project. A great number of them have already been cooperating with ZSTiO in other European programmes such as Erasmus+, Leonardo da Vinci and EFS POKL.
The main reason why students and graduates will go for apprenticeship training abroad, is their professional development, understanding the issues commonly faced by foreign based companies commencing operations in a field that relates to the students degree, a comparison of working methods in Poland with those applied in other European countries, gaining international team-work experience and getting to know different solutions in the previously mentioned industries. In addition, there is also a need to improve students’ language skills (professional English) and the recognition of other cultures in different European countries (including work and organizational culture).
The main purpose of this project is to meet our students and graduates’ needs as mentioned above. Moreover, the aim of the project is to draw the attention to improve European mobility in vocational education and training, improvement in cooperation within educational facilities and institutions, to facilitate the improvement of vocational training and internships, the improvement of transparency and the formal recognition of vocational qualifications, supporting information technology as well as the improvement of European dimension.
Expected outcomes result from the needs and objectives of the project. The most important include: easier entry into the job market after graduation (finding jobs more easily) or setting up one’s own business (the unemployment rate in 2017 was 16% according to Labour Office in Bytom), building self-confidence in new, challenging situations, coping with stress, overcoming both language and cultural barriers, enhancing the awareness of European dimension within the school community, teaching constructive thinking and drawing proper conclusions, regional school promotion/publicity.
Both the students and graduates are chosen in the recruitment process, on the basis of relevant, transparent criteria. Most of the participants are of legal age. Teachers of the school are also directly involved in this project. They are preparing the participants for going abroad, taking into consideration substantive, cultural and language requirements. It is assumed that the project will be evaluated and disseminated after the participants have returned from the internship. The school coordinator, who is in charge of this project, will be responsible for the proper conduct of the project through the following phases (information, selection, preparation, tickets purchase, insurances, contact with students’ parents, apprenticeship, evaluation, final report). Each group (except for graduates) is accompanied by an assistant, who is responsible for the supervision, the course of internship and who takes the decisions on behalf of the headmaster.
There are no students/graduates with disabilities or special needs participating in this project.
